summary: This document is a chain of emails from December 20, 2024, discussing an FBI investigation into threats made against the Claims Administrator in a federal case involving claims by victims of Jeffrey Epstein against his estate. The emails involve FBI personnel and a U.S. Attorney, coordinating a response to the threats, which include anti-Semitic messages.

persons.name: Jed Rakoff
persons.context: Reported the threatening messages received by the Claims Administrator in a case pending before him to the Chief of the Criminal Division.

persons.name: Geoffrey Epstein
persons.role: Deceased financier, subject of victim claims
persons.context: Mentioned as the individual whose estate is the subject of the claims case where the threatened Claims Administrator is working.

connections.description: Judge Rakoff has the case involving Epstein victim claims pending before him, and the Claims Administrator is working on that case as an agent of the federal judiciary.

events.title: FBI Coordination on Threat Case
events.description: Internal FBI and U.S. Attorney's Office emails coordinate the investigation into threats against the Claims Administrator in the Epstein victim claims case.

events.title: Threats Reported to FBI
events.description: U.S. District Judge Jed Rakoff reports that the Claims Administrator in the Epstein victim claims case has been receiving threatening, harassing, and anti-Semitic messages via email and Twitter/X.

keyFacts: The Claims Administrator for the federal case involving claims by victims of Jeffrey Epstein against his estate was receiving threatening and anti-Semitic messages in December 2024.

U.S. District Judge Jed Rakoff, who is presiding over the Epstein victim claims case, personally reported the threats to the Chief of the Criminal Division of the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York.
The FBI's Violent Crime Threat Cell in New York was involved in investigating the threats, with an agent having conducted a telephonic interview with the victim.
The victim (Claims Administrator) stated she was not necessarily worried about physical violence but more about violence fomented from online vitriol.
The document shows ongoing security and harassment concerns related to the Epstein case years after his death, targeting officials involved in the victim compensation process.
